Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Mini-Subvastus and Standard Medial Parapatellar Approaches in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Background: Minimally invasive surgical (MIS) techniques in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) are suggested to enhance recovery and reduce pain, but their impact on gait and thigh muscle strength remains uncertain.

Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, 40 patients undergoing TKA were randomised to either a mini-subvastus approach or a standard medial parapatellar approach. The unit of randomisation was the individual patient. Participants were evaluated preoperatively and 2 months postoperatively. Subjective functional outcomes and quality of life (QOL) were assessed using SF-12, Knee Society Score (KSS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), UCLA activity, and a patient milestone diary. Isometric thigh muscle strength and gait were evaluated using three-dimensional analysis during level walking and stair climbing. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: Both groups showed improvements in functional scores, QOL, and gait parameters. Isometric quadriceps strength increased but remained lower than sound limbs. No significant differences were found between groups in KSS, SF-12, KOOS, UCLA activity, patient milestone diary, isometric strength, or gait parameters, except for a marginally higher stair ascent speed in the MIS group. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The MIS approach does not provide a substantial early functional advantage over the standard approach in TKA.
